trans-unit.source: Defines a print job in detail.
This class has no public constructor.

To get a reference to a PrintSystemJobInfo object, use the static <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Get%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method or one of the following <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue> instance methods: <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.GetJob%2A>, <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.GetPrintJobInfoCollection%2A>, or <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.AddJob%2A>.

Many print job properties, such as whether a job is completed, must be passed from the printer to the PrintSystemJobInfo object before your application reads the corresponding property (<xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.IsCompleted%2A>).
The <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Refresh%2A> method provides this functionality.
Similarly, when your application changes the value of the <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.JobName%2A> property, the change must be written to the print queue utility on the computer.
The <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Commit%2A> method provides this functionality.

If you derive a class from PrintSystemJobInfo that has additional writable properties, then you must implement an override of the <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Refresh%2A> and <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Commit%2A> methods.
> [!CAUTION] > Classes within the <xref:System.Printing> namespace are not supported for use within a Windows service or ASP.NET application or service.
Attempting to use these classes from within one of these application types may produce unexpected problems, such as diminished service performance and run-time exceptions.
If you want to print from a Windows Forms application, see the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing> namespace.
Cancels the print job.
Writes any changes to the properties of the <xref href="System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo"></xref> object to the actual print job that the object represents.
Only the <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.JobName%2A> property is writable.

If you derive a class from <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> that has additional writable properties, you must override the Commit and <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Refresh%2A> methods with implementations of your own.
Gets the <xref href="System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo"></xref> for the specified job in the specified <xref href="System.Printing.PrintQueue"></xref>.
You can also use the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.GetJob%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method for the same purpose.
The print queue hosting the print job.
A numerical ID for the print job.
The that corresponds to the jobIdentifier.
Gets the print queue that is hosting the print job.
A <xref href="System.Printing.PrintQueue"></xref> value that represents the print queue that owns the print job.
Gets the print server that is hosting the print queue for the print job.
A <xref href="System.Printing.PrintServer"></xref> value that represents the hosting print server (usually a computer) for the <xref href="System.Printing.PrintQueue"></xref> that owns the print job.
Releases the unmanaged resources that are used by the <xref href="System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo"></xref> and optionally, releases the managed resources.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> to release both managed and unmanaged resources; <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref> to release only unmanaged resources.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job is blocked and therefore, not printing.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the print job is blocked; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job is finished.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the print job is finished; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job, which is represented by the <xref href="System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo"></xref> object, was deleted from the print queue.
It may seem paradoxical at first that an object can report its own status as deleted, but keep in mind that the <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> object only *represents* a real print job.
Deleting the latter from its print queue does not automatically dispose of the <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> object in your application.
Similarly, the object is not removed from any <xref:System.Printing.PrintJobInfoCollection> that was created before the print job it represents was deleted.

For example, if the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.GetPrintJobInfoCollection%2A> method is run before the print job was deleted, the returned collection will include a <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> object that represents the print job.
This object is not removed from the collection when the print job is deleted.
But if <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.GetPrintJobInfoCollection%2A> is then run again, the returned collection will have no members that represent the deleted print jobs.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the print job was deleted; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job is being deleted from the print queue.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the print job is being deleted; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether an error condition is associated with the print job.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if an error condition is associated with the print job; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the printer is offline.

This value is propagated to all the <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> objects from the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.IsOffline%2A> property of the hosting <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue>.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the printer is offline; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the printer has run out of the paper size and type that the print job requires.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the printer has run out of the required paper; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job is paused.
The entire print queue can also be paused.
For example, the value of IsPaused can be `false` even when the value of the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.IsPaused%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property is `true`.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the print job is paused; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job printed.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the print job has printed; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job is being printed.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the printer is printing; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job has been restarted.
When a job is restarted, it prints in its entirety.
Contrast restarting with using the <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Resume%2A> method, which resumes a job at the point it was paused.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the printer is printing; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job was saved in the queue after it printed.

A print queue retains printed jobs if the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.KeepPrintedJobs%2A> property of the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue> object is set to `true` and if the properties of the queue have been committed with the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.Commit%2A> method of the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue>.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the print job was saved; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the print job is being spooled.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the print job is being spooled; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the printer needs user intervention.

This value propagates to all <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> objects from the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.NeedUserIntervention%2A> property of the hosting <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue>.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if user intervention is needed; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets the identification number for the print job.
Which numbering system is used is determined by the operating system of the print server and whether the print server is a computer or a print server appliance.

For example, the operating system for [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_whistler](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)] determines the numbering in this way: when a print server is turned on, if all its print queues are empty, the first print job submitted on the server by any user and to any queue is assigned ID number 2.
Each subsequent job on the server is assigned a number that is one greater than the previous print job on that server.
The print queue for the print job has no effect on its number: if jobs are sent to QueueA, QueueB, and QueueA, in that order, then QueueA has jobs 2 and 4, and QueueB has job 3.
After a job is assigned a number, the number never changes, even if other jobs finish printing or are canceled, or if the server is restarted.

If there are already jobs in one or more queues when the server is restarted, the first new job is assigned a number that is one greater than the highest numbered job that was in the queue when the server started.
However, until it restarts, a print server does not reuse a number.
Even if the highest numbered job is canceled before it is printed, the next job gets a number that is one higher.
An <xref:System.Int32> that identifies the print job.
Gets or sets a name for the print job.
A <xref:System.String> name for the print job.
Get the size, in bytes, of the print job.
An <xref:System.Int32> that states the size, in bytes, of the print job.
Gets the current status of the print job.

This method gives you a means to avoid individually checking each of the status properties, such as <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.IsPrinting%2A> and <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.IsPaused%2A>.
A <xref href="System.Printing.PrintJobStatus"></xref> value.
Gets a reference to the <xref:System.IO.Stream> of the print job.
Starting with the .NET Framework 4.5 on Windows 8 and later versions of the operating system, data written to this stream must be in XPS format as a package stream.
A <xref:System.IO.Stream> that contains the print job.
Gets the number of pages in the print job.
A page is one side of a sheet of paper or other print media.

The following table shows how the value of this property, and the number of sheets used, is affected by whether the print job calls for two-sided printing (duplexing), whether it calls for multiple pages-per-sheet, or whether it calls for both.

How duplexing and multipage printing affect printing |Duplexing|Pages per sheet|Value of NumberOfPages|Number of physical sheets of paper| |---------------|---------------------|----------------------------|----------------------------------------| |No|1|Identical to the number of pages in the document.|Identical to the number of pages in the document.| |Yes|1|Identical to the number of pages in the document.|Document pages ÷ 2 (rounded up).| |No|Multiple|Document pages ÷ Pages per sheet (rounded up).|Document pages ÷ Pages per sheet (rounded up).| |Yes|Multiple|Document pages ÷ Pages per sheet (rounded up).|[Document pages ÷ Pages per sheet] ÷ 2 (rounded up).|
An <xref:System.Int32> that states the number of pages in the print job.
Gets the number of pages that have already printed.
An <xref:System.Int32> that states the number of pages that have already printed.
Halts printing of the job until <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Resume*> runs.
If another job is in the queue, it begins printing when the current job is paused.
The hosting <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue> also has <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.Pause%2A> and <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.Resume%2A> methods.
If the print queue is paused, resuming an individual job does not cause that job to resume printing.
Gets the print job's place in the print queue.
An <xref:System.Int32> that states the print job's place in the queue.
Gets a non-numerical expression that represents the priority of the print job relative to other jobs in the print queue.

A <xref href="System.Printing.PrintJobPriority"></xref> that represents the priority of the print job as <xref href="System.Printing.PrintJobPriority"></xref>, <xref href="System.Printing.PrintJobPriority"></xref>, <xref href="System.Printing.PrintJobPriority"></xref>, or <xref href="System.Printing.PrintJobPriority"></xref>.
Updates the properties of the <xref href="System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo"></xref> object so that their values match the values of the actual print job that the object represents.

Any changes that you make to the properties of a <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> object must be written to the actual print job by using the <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Commit%2A> method.
Any changes that you have not committed are lost when the Refresh method runs.
If you derive a class from <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> that has additional properties, then you must override the Refresh method with an implementation of your own.
Restarts a print job from the beginning.
Optionally, you can use the <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo.Resume%2A> method, which restarts a paused print job, starting at the point it was paused.
Resumes the printing of a paused print job.
The hosting <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue> also has <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.Pause%2A> and <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.Resume%2A> methods.
If the print queue is paused, resuming an individual job does not resume the printing of the print job.
Gets the earliest time of day, expressed as the number of minutes after midnight Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) (also called Greenwich Mean Time [GMT]), that the print job can begin printing.

This value is propagated to each <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> object from the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.StartTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property of the hosting <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue> at the time the job enters the queue.

If <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.StartTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is changed, then any StartTimeOfDay value that is earlier than <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.StartTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is changed to the value of <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.StartTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.

After the job is added to the queue, it can be given a new StartTimeOfDay value through the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_win](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)] [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_ui](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-ui-md.md)], provided that it is not earlier than <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.StartTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
If you are not in the UTC time zone, you must add or subtract multiples of 60 to get the correct time for your time zone.
For example, if you are in the Pacific Time Zone of North America and daylight savings time is not in effect, then your local time is 8 hours earlier than UTC.
If StartTimeOfDay returns 960, that means 16:00 (4:00 PM) in UTC (because 960/60 = 16).
To convert this to Pacific Time, you must subtract 480 (= 8 * 60) minutes.
You also must remember that time rolls over to zero after 24 hours (that is; after the 1439th minute).
If StartTimeOfDay returns 120, that means 2:00 AM in UTC.
To convert this to Pacific Time, you must subtract 480 minutes, which results in -360.
To get a positive value that has meaning, add the negative number to the total minutes in a day, 1440, resulting in a final value of 1080 (6:00 PM) Pacific Time.
See <xref:System.TimeZone>, <xref:System.TimeSpan>, and <xref:System.DateTime> for methods that help make time-zone adjustments.
If the printer is always available, then this property returns 0 in all time zones.
An <xref:System.Int32> specifying the earliest possible start time for the print job, expressed as the number of minutes after midnight (UTC).
The maximum value is 1439.
Gets the name of the user who submitted the print job.
A <xref:System.String> that identifies the user who submitted the print job.
Gets the date and time that the print job is submitted.
A <xref:System.DateTime> object containing the date and time that the print job is submitted.
Gets the time, in milliseconds, since the print job started printing.
An <xref:System.Int32> that represents the time, in milliseconds, since the print job started.
Gets the last time of day, expressed as the number of minutes after midnight Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) (also called Greenwich Mean Time [GMT]), that the print job can begin printing.

This value is propagated to each <xref:System.Printing.PrintSystemJobInfo> object from the <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.UntilTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property of the hosting <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue> at the time the job enters the queue.

If <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.UntilTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is changed, then any UntilTimeOfDay value that is later than <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.UntilTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is changed to the value of <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.UntilTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.

After the job is added to the queue, it can be given a new UntilTimeOfDay value through the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_win](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)] [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_ui](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-ui-md.md)], provided that it is not later than <xref:System.Printing.PrintQueue.UntilTimeOfDay%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
If you are not in the UTC time zone, you must add or subtract multiples of 60 to get the correct time for your time zone.
For example, if you are in the Pacific Time Zone of North America and daylight savings time is not in effect, then your local time is 8 hours earlier than UTC.
If UntilTimeOfDay returns 960, that means 16:00 (4:00 PM) in UTC (because 960/60 = 16).
To convert this to Pacific Time, you must subtract 480 (= 8 * 60) minutes.
You also must remember that time rolls over to zero after 24 hours (that is; after the 1439th minute).
If UntilTimeOfDay returns 120, that means 2:00 AM in UTC.
To convert this to Pacific Time, you must subtract 480 minutes, which results in -360.
To get a positive value that has meaning, add the negative number to the total minutes in a day, 1440, resulting in a final value of 1080 (6:00 PM) Pacific Time.
See <xref:System.TimeZone>, <xref:System.TimeSpan>, and <xref:System.DateTime> for methods that help make time-zone adjustments.
If the printer is always available, then this property returns 0 in all time zones.
An <xref:System.Int32> that specifies the last time that the job can print, expressed as the number of minutes after midnight (UTC).
The maximum value is 1439.
